column1: Northfield is a city in Dakota and Rice counties in the State of Minnesota. It is mostly in Rice County
column2: with a small portion in Dakota County. The population was 20

column1: Northfield was platted in 1856 by John W. North. Local legend says that the town was named for John North and for a Mr. Field. North
column2: realizing that the town straddled the proposed northern border of Rice county
column3: went to the state capital to lobby to move the border one mile north. Northfield was founded by settlers from New England known as "Yankees" as part of New England's colonization of what was then the far west. It was an early agricultural center with many wheat and corn farms. The town also supported lumber and flour mills powered by the Cannon River. As the "wheat frontier" moved west
column4: dairy operations and diversified farms replaced wheat-based agriculture. The region has since moved away from dairy and beef operations. Today it produces substantial crops of corn and soybeans
column5: as well as hogs. The local cereal producer Malt-O-Meal is one of the few remnants of Northfield's historic wheat boom. The city's motto
column9: reflects the influence of the dairy farms as well as its two liberal arts colleges
column10: Carleton College and St. Olaf College.

column2: Northfield has been a center of higher education. Carleton College (then Northfield College) was founded in 1869 on the northern edge of town by the Minnesota Conference of Congregational churches whose Congregation consisted of the "Yankee" settlers who had largely founded the town. These were people descended from the English Puritans who settled New England in the 1600s. St. Olaf College was founded in 1874 on the western edge of town by Norwegian Lutheran immigrant pastors and farmers
column3: who were eager to preserve their faith and culture by training teachers and preachers. These two institutions

column2: completion of Interstate 35 six miles west of Northfield enabled the expansion of the Minneapolis–Saint Paul metro area south of the Minnesota River. The downtown grain elevator accepted its last load of corn in 2000 and was torn down in 2002. Residential growth has been rapid since the mid-1990s. Northfield Hospital
column3: which opened in 2003 in the town's northwest corner
column5: so chosen because government reimbursement rates are more generous for Dakota County than for Rice County.

column3: the town is centered around the Cannon River and rises both to the east and the west away from this bisecting river body.

column1: Jesse James' and the James-Younger Gang's 1876 attempt to rob the First National Bank of Northfield serves as a heritage tourism draw for the town. The original bank building was converted to a museum operated by the Northfield Historical Society. The First National Bank of Northfield operates from a main office built half a block away from the historic site. In its front lobby
column2: a glass case showcases a gun used during the robbery.

column1: The Northfield Convention and Visitors Bureau provides comprehensive tourism information and visit planning services.
=== Defeat of Jesse James Days Celebration ===

column3: Northfield experienced one of its most important historical events
column4: when The James-Younger Gang attempted a robbery on the First National Bank of Northfield. Local citizens
column6: armed themselves and resisted the robbers and successfully thwarted the theft. The gang killed the bank's cashier
column7: Joseph Lee Heywood and a Swedish immigrant
column8: Nicholas Gustafson. A couple of members of the gang were killed in the street
column10: Bob and Jim Younger were cornered near Madelia
column11: Minnesota. Jesse and Frank James escaped west into the Dakotas
column12: while the remaining gang members were killed or taken into custody.  Considering the James gang as related to postwar insurgency
column13: the raid has sometimes been called the last major event of the American Civil War. Two of Northfield's slogans are "Jesse James Slipped Here"

column1: The events have become the basis of an annual outdoor heritage festival called The Defeat of Jesse James Days. It is held the weekend after Labor Day and is among the largest outdoor celebrations in Minnesota. Thousands of visitors witness reenactments of the robbery
column2: which is staged on Division street
column3: outside of the First National Bank of Northfield. Other activities during the festival include: a championship rodeo
column7: as well as arts and crafts expositions
column8: and musical performances. Many food stations are set up in Bridge Square
column9: and during the evenings live music is played in a "beer tent" on Water Street. A horseshoe hunt takes place the week prior to the celebration; an antique horseshoe is hidden somewhere within the city on public grounds and the finder claims that year's cash purse.

column1: Films based on the failed raid include The True Story of Jesse James (1957)
Northfield was also the setting of the TV-movie Love Always
The city owns 35 parks consisting of over 400 acres (1.6 km2) of land.  Three of these parks have picnic shelters.The Carleton College Cowling Arboretum is a sizable
column2: well-established arboretum and nature preserve adjacent to and owned by Carleton College. It offers extensive trails for walking in the summer and cross-country skiing in the winter.

column1: St. Olaf College also owns many hundreds of acres called the St. Olaf Natural Lands. These include 350 acres (1.4 km2) of natural habitat and 444 acres (1.80 km2) acres of agricultural land. Of that
column2: 150 acres (0.61 km2) is restored prairie with 10 species of native grasses
column4: 15 acres (0.061 km2) of big woods habitat
column5: and up to 9 acres (0.036 km2) of surface wetlands. The St. Olaf Natural Lands are open to the public all year long.The Mill Towns State Trail was built in 1998 as a joint effort of the cities of Northfield and Dundas.

column1: The City of Northfield operates as a Mayor-Council form of government. The City Administrator is responsible for managing daily operations. The current mayor is Rhonda Pownell. The city council consists of six members
column2: four of whom represent city districts and two of whom are at-large members serving four year terms.Northfield is served by Minnesota State Senator Rich Draheim (RPM) in District 20 and State Representative Todd Lippert (DFL) in District 20B.
Northfield is part of Minnesota's 2nd congressional district
column4: and in the Senate by Tina Smith and Amy Klobuchar
column5: both members of Minnesota's Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party
column6: an affiliate of the Democratic Party.

column1: Northfield is home to St. Olaf and Carleton colleges. Their student and staff populations account for a large portion of the town's year-round population.
The Northfield Public School district operates three elementary schools
column4: and an alternative learning center. In addition
column5: Northfield has public charter schools: Arcadia (grades 6–12) and Prairie Creek Community School (grades K–5) in nearby Castle Rock. They receive state funding from the State of Minnesota.
